author: roberts
text:
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES_________________No. 20–157_________________EDWARD A. CANIGLIA, PETITIONERv.ROBERT F. STROM, et al.on writ of certiorari to the united states
court of appeals for the first circuit[May 17, 2021]Chief Justice Roberts, with whom Justice
Breyer joins, concurring.Fifteen years ago, this Court unanimously
recognized that “[t]he role of a peace officer includes preventing
violence and restoring order, not simply rendering first aid to
casualties.”Brigham Cityv.Stuart,547 U.S.
398, 406 (2006). A warrant to enter a home is not required, we
explained, when there is a “need to assist persons who are
seriously injured or threatened with such injury.”Id.,at
403; see alsoMichiganv.Fisher,558 U.S.
45, 49 (2009) (per curiam) (warrantless entry justified
where “there was an objectively reasonable basis for believing that
medical assistance was needed, or persons were in danger” (internal
quotation marks omitted)). Nothing in today’s opinion is to the
contrary, and I join it on that basis.
